name: Stari Most
description: A 16th-century Ottoman bridge crossing the Neretva river, a symbol of the city and a UNESCO World Heritage site.
fun_fact: Local divers jump from the bridge into the cold Neretva river as a traditional rite of passage.

name: Baščaršija
description: The historical and cultural center of Sarajevo, established in the 15th century as a market hub.It is the epicenter of Sarajevo's food culture.
keywords: market, bazaar, crafts, cevapi, burek, coffee, tradition,sebilj, old town
fun_fact: The name Baščaršija derives from the Turkish words 'baş' (head) and 'çarşı' (market).

name: Kastel Fortress
description: A historic fortress situated on the left bank of the Vrbas river, containing remains of Roman and Ottoman fortifications.
fun_fact: The fortress is one of the oldest buildings in Bosnia and Herzegovina with traces of Neolithic settlements.

name: Kamene kugle (Stone Spheres)
description: Large, mysterious spherical stone formations found in the forest near Zavidovići.
fun_fact: The largest sphere is estimated to weigh over 30 tons, making it one of the largest in Europe.

name: Bosnian Pyramid of the Sun
description: A hillsite claimed by some to be the largest man-made ancient pyramid in the world.
fun_fact: The Ravne tunnels underneath the pyramids are claimed to have high concentrations of negative ions.

name: Obelisk near Olovo
description: A mysterious 14th-century stone monolith decorated with carvings of a boar, a snake, and a crescent.
fun_fact: The obelisk is a unique monument of the Bosnian Church, likely marking the tomb of a high-ranking noble.

name: Lukomir Village
description: The highest and most isolated mountain village in Bosnia and Herzegovina, preserving traditional lifestyles.
keywords: mountains, hiking, traditional, village, high altitude
fun_fact: Lukomir is unique for its stone houses with cherry wood roof tiles.

name: AVNOJ Museum
description: The building where the Second Session of the Anti-Fascist Council for the National Liberation of Yugoslavia was held in 1943.
fun_fact: Socialist Yugoslavia was officially born within these walls during the 1943 assembly.

name: Tjentište (Sutjeska Memorial)
description: A massive brutalist monument commemorating the Battle of the Sutjeska during WWII.
fun_fact: The monument was designed by Miodrag Živković and is one of the most iconic Spomeniks in the Balkans.

name: Mehmed Paša Sokolović Bridge
description: A 16th-century Ottoman bridge designed by Mimar Sinan and featured in Ivo Andrić's famous novel.
fun_fact: The bridge is the central 'character' in the Nobel-prize winning novel 'The Bridge on the Drina'.

name: Blagaj Tekke
description: A Dervish monastery built into a 200m cliff next to the source of the Buna river.
fun_fact: The Buna river spring is one of the largest and most powerful karst springs in Europe.

name: Radimlja Stećci Necropolis
description: One of the most important medieval tombstones (stećci) sites in Bosnia, featuring intricate carvings.
fun_fact: The site features 133 tombstones, many with the iconic 'man with a raised hand' relief.

name: Vijećnica (City Hall)
description: The most iconic building in Sarajevo, built in a pseudo-Moorish style, formerly the National Library.
fun_fact: The building was completely destroyed during the Siege of Sarajevo and reopened in 2014 after restoration.

name: Počitelj
description: A historic fortified town on the banks of the Neretva, a living museum of Ottoman architecture.
fun_fact: The town's Gavrankapetanović house was one of the first artist colonies in Southeast Europe.

name: Jajce Fortress
description: The seat of the last Bosnian kings, overlooking the famous 22-meter high Pliva waterfall.
fun_fact: Jajce is the only city in the world with a natural waterfall in its very center.

name: Bobovac
description: The royal city and residence of Bosnian kings during the medieval period.
fun_fact: The Bosnian royal crown was kept here for safety due to its strategic, hard-to-reach location.

name: Tvrđava Srebrenik
description: The best-preserved medieval fortress in Bosnia, perched on a steep rock cliff.
fun_fact: It was the historical seat of the Ban Stjepan II Kotromanić, who issued the famous charter there in 1333.

name: Kozara Monument
description: A revolutionary monument dedicated to the fallen fighters and civilians of the Battle of Kozara.
fun_fact: The monument is designed to symbolize the struggle between light and darkness.

name: Mogorjelo
description: Remains of a 4th-century Roman villa rustica, one of the most important Roman sites in the country.
fun_fact: The site was originally a private farm and estate before being converted into a fortress.

name: Vjetrenica Cave
description: The largest and most important cave in Bosnia and Herzegovina, known for its biodiversity.
fun_fact: It is the richest cave in the world in terms of subterranean biodiversity.

name: Kraljeva Sutjeska
description: The site of a Franciscan monastery and the ruins of a medieval royal court.
fun_fact: It was the residence of the last Bosnian Queen, Katarina, who is still mourned by local women wearing black headscarves.

name: Partisan Memorial Cemetery
description: A monumental necropolis built to honor the Yugoslav partisans from Mostar.
fun_fact: Designed by architect Bogdan Bogdanović, it resembles a stone city with flowered terraces.

name: Daorson
description: The ruins of the ancient capital of the Hellenized Illyrian tribe known as the Daorsi.
keywords: Illyrian, ancient city, cyclopean walls, archeology
fun_fact: The site features massive cyclopean walls built without mortar, similar to Mycenae.

name: Tešanj Fortress
description: One of the largest and most significant fortresses in the country, with foundations from the 15th century.
fun_fact: The fortress has a 17-meter high clock tower that is still operational today.

name: Stari Grad Ostrožac
description: A unique castle featuring a mix of medieval, Ottoman, and Neo-Gothic architectural styles.
fun_fact: It contains an outdoor sculpture park with works from international artists.

name: Tvrđava Doboj
description: A 13th-century fortress that served as a key defensive point in the Bosna river valley.
fun_fact: The fortress was attacked and besieged over 50 times throughout history.

name: Museum of Contemporary Art (MSURS)
description: A leading cultural institution located in the former Banja Luka railway station.
fun_fact: The building itself is a protected national monument of architecture.

name: Konjic Old Bridge
description: A beautiful 17th-century Ottoman bridge that connects the two banks of the Neretva.
fun_fact: The bridge was destroyed by the retreating German army in 1945 and rebuilt in 2009.

name: Tito's Bunker (ARK D-0)
description: A secret nuclear bunker built to protect Yugoslav leader Josip Broz Tito and 350 others.
keywords: Cold War, bunker, secret, Tito, Yugoslavia
fun_fact: It remained a state secret for decades, known only to a handful of high-ranking officials.

name: Fethija Mosque
description: Originally built as a Catholic church in 1266, it was converted into a mosque in 1592.
fun_fact: It is one of the few examples of Gothic architecture that was preserved in Bosnia.

name: Gradačac Fortress (Gradina)
description: The fortress of Husein Kapetan Gradaščević, known as the 'Dragon of Bosnia'.
keywords: castle, Dragon of Bosnia, history, tower
fun_fact: The 18-meter high watchtower offers a panoramic view of the entire Posavina region.

name: Travnik Fortress (Stari Grad)
description: A medieval fortress that became a center of Ottoman administration for the Viziers.
fun_fact: Travnik was the capital of the Ottoman governors (Viziers) of Bosnia for 150 years.

name: Birth House of Ivo Andrić
description: A museum dedicated to the Nobel Prize-winning author of 'The Bridge on the Drina'.
fun_fact: The museum showcases the authentic interior of a 19th-century Bosnian house.

name: Trebinje Old Town (Kastel)
description: The historic walled center of Trebinje, located on the banks of the Trebišnjica river.
fun_fact: Trebinje is often called the 'City of Sun and Plane Trees'.

name: Arslanagić Bridge
description: A 16th-century Ottoman bridge, moved stone by stone from its original location due to a dam.
fun_fact: The bridge was relocated in 1972 to save it from the rising waters of a hydroelectric lake.

name: War Tunnel Museum (Tunel Spasa)
description: The secret underground tunnel that kept Sarajevo supplied during the 1990s siege.
fun_fact: The tunnel was the only way for food and medicine to enter the city during the 1,425-day siege.

name: Latin Bridge
description: An Ottoman bridge where the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand took place in 1914.
fun_fact: This site is widely considered the location where World War I was triggered.

name: Gazi Husrev-beg Mosque
description: The largest historical mosque in Bosnia and Herzegovina and one of the most representative Ottoman structures in the Balkans.
fun_fact: It was the first mosque in the world to receive electric lighting for its interior.

name: Srebrenica-Potočari Memorial
description: A memorial and cemetery complex for the victims of the 1995 Srebrenica genocide.
fun_fact: The memorial contains the names of over 8,000 victims of the genocide.

name: National Museum of Bosnia and Herzegovina
description: The oldest modern cultural institution in the country, housing the famous Sarajevo Haggadah.
fun_fact: The Sarajevo Haggadah is a 14th-century illuminated manuscript and one of the most valuable items in the museum.

name: Prokoško Lake Katuni
description: High-altitude shepherd settlements around a glacial lake, showcasing traditional livestock farming.
fun_fact: The lake is home to the endemic Triton (Triturus alpestris reiseri), a rare amphibian.

name: Umoljani Village
description: An ancient mountain village with a dragon legend and unique stone architecture.
fun_fact: A rock formation above the village is said to be the petrified tail of a legendary dragon.

name: Boljuni Stećci Necropolis
description: A significant medieval necropolis with high artistic value in its tombstone carvings.
fun_fact: The site has the highest number of inscriptions among all medieval necropolises in Bosnia.

name: St. Anthony of Padua Monastery
description: A significant Catholic monastery that was visited by Pope John Paul II in 2003.
fun_fact: The monastery was completely destroyed in 1995 and subsequently rebuilt as a modern architectural piece.

name: Ferhadija Mosque
description: A masterpiece of Ottoman architecture, destroyed in 1993 and painstakingly reconstructed stone by stone.
fun_fact: The reconstruction used as many of the original stone fragments as possible, fished out of the river.

name: Atik Mosque
description: One of the oldest mosques in Semberija, featuring a unique wooden minaret in its history.
fun_fact: The site also houses several old gravestones (nišani) of significant historical families.

name: Livno Wild Horses Plateau
description: A vast natural plateau, famous for its wild horses and the production of high-quality Livanjski sir cheese.
keywords: wild horses, livanjski sir, cheese, food, nature
fun_fact: The horses are descendants of domestic animals left behind when tractors replaced them in the 1970s. Also,Livanjski sir is a protected national cheese brand, originally made in the 19th century based on a French recipe.

name: Tvrđava Maglaj
description: A medieval fortress built on a high rock above the Bosna river.
fun_fact: The fortress has a distinctive triangular layout adapted to the shape of the rock it sits on.

name: Sarajevo Spite House (Inat kuća)
description: A house moved stone by stone from one side of the river to the other to make room for the City Hall.
fun_fact: The house remains a symbol of Bosnian defiance and stubbornness against authority.

name: Prusac (Ajvatovica)
description: The site of the largest Muslim pilgrimage in Europe, celebrating a 500-year-old legend.
fun_fact: According to legend, Ajvaz Dedo prayed for 40 days for water until a massive rock split in half.

name: Buna Canals (Bunski Kanali)
description: A natural phenomenon where the Buna river flows into the Neretva through narrow, sculpted channels.
fun_fact: It is one of the most beautiful natural river junctions in the Balkans but remains largely unknown to tourists.

name: Jewish Cemetery
description: The second largest Jewish burial ground in Europe, after the one in Prague.
fun_fact: The cemetery features unique 'Sarajevo-style' tombstones that resemble medieval stećci.

name: Kulen Vakuf Fortress (Ostrovica)
description: A massive medieval fortress overlooking the Una river valley in the Una National Park.
fun_fact: The fortress was a key strategic point between the Ottoman and Austro-Hungarian empires.

name: Roman Bridge at Plandište
description: A bridge built in the 16th century using authentic Roman stone blocks from nearby ruins.
fun_fact: Despite its name, the bridge is Ottoman, but it gets the name from the Roman stones used in its construction.

name: Husein-kapetan Gradaščević House
description: The family home of the leader of the Bosnian uprising against the Ottoman Empire.
fun_fact: The interior is preserved with authentic 19th-century furniture and personal belongings of the Captain.

name: Tešanj Clock Tower
description: One of the few clock towers in Bosnia that still keeps accurate time for the local community.
fun_fact: The tower has survived several major fires and wars throughout its 300-year history.

name: Zavala Monastery
description: A Serbian Orthodox monastery carved into a cliff, dating back to the 9th century according to legend.
fun_fact: The monastery is located at the edge of Popovo Polje, one of the largest karst fields in the world.

name: Srebrenik Old Town
description: The ruins of the old administrative center surrounding the famous Srebrenik fortress.
fun_fact: Excavations have revealed several layers of habitation dating back to the prehistoric era.

name: Livno Dumana Spring
description: A karst spring of the river Bistrica located at the foot of the Bašajkovac hill.
fun_fact: The site features a stone bridge from the Ottoman period that frames the rushing water.

name: Musić Begovina
description: A residential complex showcasing the high-style living of 19th-century Bosnian nobility.
fun_fact: It is one of the best examples of the residential culture of the Ottoman era in Herzegovina.

name: Vranduk Fortress
description: A medieval table-fortress located on a hill above the Bosna river, once a residence of kings.
fun_fact: Vranduk is known as the 'Gate of Bosnia' because it controlled the main north-south valley.

name: Old Town Stolac (Vidoški)
description: A massive stone fortress with 13 towers, one of the largest in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
fun_fact: The fortress sits on a site that has been fortified since the Illyrian and Roman times.

name: Sokolac Fortress
description: A unique medieval tower perched on a steep hill overlooking the Una river valley.
fun_fact: The fortress was a key strategic point for the Frankopan family during the medieval era.

name: Vrelo Bosne
description: The source of the Bosna river, featuring a park with thermal springs and Austro-Hungarian bridges.
fun_fact: Visitors often arrive via a 3.5 km long alley of plane and chestnut trees in horse-drawn carriages.

name: Herceg Stjepan Fortress
description: The ruins of a fortress once belonging to the Duke of St. Sava, overlooking the Blagaj Tekke.
keywords: castle, Blagaj, history, panoramic, Duke Stjepan
fun_fact: It was the seat of the Kosača noble family, who gave the region of Herzegovina its name.

name: Bijela Tabija (White Fortress)
description: A national monument overlooking the city, part of the old Vratnik walled city.
fun_fact: It offers one of the best panoramic views of Sarajevo's skyline and the Miljacka canyon.

name: Žuta Tabija (Yellow Bastion)
description: An 18th-century cannon fortress that served as a key point in the city's defense.
fun_fact: During Ramadan, a cannon is fired from here to mark the time for Iftar (breaking the fast).

name: Završje Old Town
description: A lesser-known fortified settlement from the medieval and Ottoman periods.
fun_fact: This site is part of a series of fortifications that defended the western borders of the Bosnian kingdom.

name: Atmejdan Park & Archeological Site
description: An urban park containing the ruins of the 16th-century Bakr-Baba Mosque and a traditional madrasa.
fun_fact: The name 'Atmejdan' literally means 'Horse Square' in Turkish, as it was a horse market.

name: Museum of the Jews of BiH
description: Located in the oldest synagogue in Sarajevo (Old Temple), showcasing 450 years of Jewish history.
fun_fact: The museum is housed in a building from 1581 that survived multiple fires and wars.

name: Franciscan Monastery Museum Fojnica
description: Home to the Ahdnama, a 15th-century document granting religious freedom to Franciscans.
fun_fact: The Ahdnama is one of the oldest human rights documents in the Balkans, issued by Mehmed the Conqueror.

name: Museum of Old Orthodox Church
description: A 16th-century church containing a world-class collection of icons and liturgical objects.
fun_fact: The church is unique for its architectural plan, which is much wider than it is long.

name: Kraljeva Sutjeska Dusper House
description: The oldest surviving authentic Bosnian house in the Central Bosnia region.
fun_fact: The house remains a perfect example of the 'musafirhana' or guest-house tradition.

name: Bijambare Caves and Park
description: A protected landscape featuring five caves and high mountain meadows.
fun_fact: The 'Main Cave' is known for its incredible natural acoustics, often called the Music Hall.

name: Stara Pravoslavna Crkva
description: A 19th-century Orthodox church overlooking the city, rebuilt after being destroyed in 1992.
fun_fact: The original church was a symbol of Mostar’s multicultural landscape before the war.

name: Andrićgrad (Višegrad)
description: A cultural complex dedicated to Ivo Andrić, designed by filmmaker Emir Kusturica.
fun_fact: The 'city' is built from stone to resemble a medieval town that never actually existed.

name: Musić-begovina House
description: An architectural complex representing the lifestyle of the Musić family in the 19th century.
fun_fact: The house is a key example of the Mediterranean-influenced Ottoman residential style.

name: Stećci Necropolis Bijača
description: A small but significant necropolis of medieval tombstones near the border with Croatia.
fun_fact: It is one of the 28 sites inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage list of Stećci.

name: Fortress of Bočac
description: Ruins of a medieval fortress perched on a cliff above the Vrbas river canyon.
fun_fact: The fortress guarded the strategic crossing of the Vrbas river toward the south.

name: Museum of Woodcarving
description: The Mulić’s Record museum, keeping the UNESCO-protected woodcarving tradition alive.
fun_fact: Konjic woodcarving was officially inscribed on the UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage list in 2017.

name: Srebrenica Old Town
description: Not the fortress, but the ruins of the medieval silver mining town that once rivaled Dubrovnik.
fun_fact: During the 14th century, this was one of the most prosperous economic centers in the Balkans.

name: Pocitelj Sahat-kula (Clock Tower)
description: The stone clock tower that dominates the skyline of the historic town of Počitelj.
fun_fact: Unlike most Bosnian clock towers, this one does not have a clock face, as bells were used to tell time.

name: Hamam in Stolac
description: The remains of a 16th-century public bathhouse, showcasing Ottoman hydraulic engineering.
fun_fact: The Silahdar Husein-pasha hamam is one of the few preserved public baths in Herzegovina.

name: Despić House
description: A house belonging to a wealthy Orthodox family, showcasing the birth of theater in the city.
fun_fact: The first theater performances in Sarajevo were held in the large hall of this house.

name: Hadži Ali-bey Mosque
description: A unique mosque in Travnik with a sundial on its wall, still functional today.
fun_fact: It is the only mosque in Bosnia and Herzegovina that possesses a functional vertical sundial.

name: Svrzo's House
description: The most preserved example of a wealthy Ottoman-style merchant house in Sarajevo.
fun_fact: The house is divided into 'Selamluk' (public area) and 'Haremluk' (private family area).

name: Muslibegović House
description: A national monument and luxury hotel that preserves the layout of a 19th-century noble house.
fun_fact: It is often cited as one of the most beautiful examples of Ottoman residential architecture in the Balkans.

name: Trebinje Clock Tower
description: An 18th-century tower built by the Hadžismatović family in the center of the Old Town.
fun_fact: The tower was built using the famous local Herzegovina limestone.

name: Tvrđava Bužim
description: A Renaissance-style fortress and the old town of the noble Frankopan family.
fun_fact: It is one of the few fortresses in Bosnia with a clear Renaissance polygonal bastioned layout.

name: Ostrovica Castle
description: A massive fortification on a hill above Kulen Vakuf, offering a bird's eye view of the Una.
fun_fact: The castle was a key stronghold for the Bosnian kingdom against Hungarian expansion.

name: Kraljeva Sutjeska Library
description: A monastery library containing 31 incunabula (books printed before 1501).
fun_fact: It is the most important collection of medieval and early modern books in the country.

name: Djevojačka Pećina (Maiden's Cave)
description: A cave with prehistoric carvings and a legend about a brave young girl.
fun_fact: Every August, thousands of people visit the cave for a traditional prayer meeting.

name: Vraca Memorial Park
description: A WWII memorial complex built on the site of an Austro-Hungarian fortress.
fun_fact: The names of over 11,000 victims of WWII are inscribed on the stone walls of the park.

name: History Museum of BiH
description: A museum focused on the 20th-century history of Bosnia, including a permanent exhibit on the Siege.
fun_fact: The museum building is a masterpiece of Yugoslav modernist architecture, despite its battle-scarred exterior.

name: Jewish Museum of Mostar
description: A small community-run museum located in the reconstructed synagogue of Mostar.
fun_fact: The museum tells the story of Mostar's Sephardic Jewish community which was almost wiped out in WWII.

name: Krušnica River Source
description: A stunning karst spring accessible only by boat or hiking through the forest.
fun_fact: The water at the source is so pure that it is bottled directly by local residents.

name: Old Bridge of Višegrad (Arada)
description: The remains of an even older bridge near the famous Mehmed Paša bridge.
fun_fact: Local legends say this older crossing was used by caravans long before Sinan built the grand bridge.

name: Sinan-Begova Mosque
description: An 16th-century architectural gem known for its unique stone carvings and history.
fun_fact: It was one of the most beautiful mosques in eastern Bosnia before its destruction and recent reconstruction.

name: Stećci Necropolis Mramorje
description: A medieval cemetery located on the banks of the Drina river.
fun_fact: The site is part of the trans-border UNESCO protection of medieval tombstones.

name: Fortress of Ključ
description: A large fortress on a cliff above the Sana river where the last Bosnian king was captured.
fun_fact: It was here that King Stjepan Tomašević surrendered to the Ottoman Sultan Mehmed II in 1463.

name: Srebrenik Fortress
description: One of the best-preserved medieval castles in BiH, perched on a massive rock.
fun_fact: It was the historical seat of Ban Stjepan II Kotromanić, who issued a famous charter here in 1333.

name: Ostrožac Castle
description: A unique castle featuring both a medieval fortress and a 19th-century Habsburg-style wing.
fun_fact: It houses a unique outdoor sculpture garden within the walls.

name: Štrbački Buk
description: The highest and most spectacular waterfall on the Una River.
fun_fact: Located within the Una National Park on the border with Croatia.

name: Martin Brod
description: A complex of waterfalls and ancient watermills at the confluence of Una and Unac.
fun_fact: Famous for its traditional wool-washing 'natural washing machines'.

name: Prokoško Lake
description: A glacial lake surrounded by traditional wooden shepherd huts on Vranica mountain.
fun_fact: Home to the endemic Triton (Triturus alpestris reiseri) salamander.

name: Lukomir Village
description: Bosnia's highest and most isolated mountain village with traditional stone houses.
fun_fact: Residents still wear traditional hand-knitted wool clothing.

name: Daorson
description: Remains of a Hellenistic city built by the Illyrian tribe of Daorsi.
fun_fact: The massive 'cyclopean' stone blocks resemble Mycenaean architecture.

name: Mogorjelo
description: Extremely well-preserved ruins of a Roman 'Villa Rustica'.
fun_fact: The site was once a major agricultural production center for the Romans.

name: Vjetrenica Cave
description: The largest and most important cave in BiH, famous for its biodiversity.
fun_fact: It is the richest cave in the world in terms of cave-dwelling animals and a UNESCO site since 2024.

name: Tešanj Fortress
description: One of the largest and most significant fortification complexes in Bosnia.
fun_fact: The fortress has a 17-meter high clock tower that is still operational today.

name: Doboj Fortress
description: A strategic medieval fortress guarding the Bosna river valley.
fun_fact: It has been destroyed and rebuilt over 20 times throughout history.

name: Gradačac Castle
description: Features the famous 'Dragon of Bosnia' tower overlooking the town.
fun_fact: Built by Husein-kapetan Gradaščević, a leader of the Bosnian autonomy movement.

name: Travnik Fortress
description: Medieval fortress in the heart of the former capital of Bosnian Viziers.
fun_fact: The only fortress in the country with a clock tower built inside.

name: Šarena Džamija
description: Known as the 'Painted Mosque' due to its unique floral exterior murals.
fun_fact: It is one of the very few mosques globally with a market (bezistan) inside its ground floor.

name: Panonska Jezera
description: Artificial salt lakes located in the city center, unique in Europe.
keywords: salt lake, swimming, tuzla, cevapi, Limenka
fun_fact: The salt is pumped from natural underground deposits under the city.

name: Mariastern Abbey
description: Trappist monastery famous for its unique cheese production.
fun_fact: It was once the only Trappist monastery in Southeastern Europe.

name: Krupa na Vrbasu
description: Natural area with cascades and ancient watermills near a medieval monastery.
fun_fact: Famous for its wood-shingle mills that are still operational.

name: Zelengora Lakes
description: A series of 8 glacial lakes known as 'Mountain Eyes'.
fun_fact: Considered by many to be the most beautiful mountain in the Dinarides.

name: Perućica Forest
description: One of the two last remaining primeval forests in Europe.
fun_fact: Includes the 75-meter high Skakavac waterfall, hidden deep in the forest.

name: Tvrdoš Monastery
description: 15th-century Orthodox monastery famous for its wine cellars.
fun_fact: Built on the foundations of a 4th-century Roman church.

name: Arslanagić Bridge
description: An elegant Ottoman bridge relocated stone-by-stone to its current location.
fun_fact: It was moved in the 1970s to save it from a hydroelectric dam project.

name: Žitomislić Monastery
description: One of the most important Orthodox monasteries in Herzegovina.
fun_fact: Known for its museum of icons and manuscripts.

name: Bliha Falls
description: A stunning 56-meter waterfall where the river falls over a vertical cliff.
fun_fact: The waterfall is also known as 'Blihin Skakavac'.

name: Hutovo Blato
description: A nature reserve and bird sanctuary, one of the largest in the Balkans.
fun_fact: It is a major wintering ground for over 240 species of migratory birds.

name: Japodski Otoci
description: A unique eco-tourism site consisting of river islands shaped like a heart.
fun_fact: Designed to resemble an ancient Japodian settlement.

name: Kozara National Park
description: Site of a major WWII battle and home to a monumental memorial sculpture.
fun_fact: Known as the 'Green Heart of Krajina'.

name: Hajdučka Vrata
description: A natural stone arch formed by wind erosion on the Čvrsnica mountain.
fun_fact: One of the most photographed natural landmarks for hikers in BiH.

name: Maglaj Fortress
description: Dominates the old town and has a unique five-sided tower.
fun_fact: The fortress has a rare combination of medieval and ottoman defensive styles.

name: Ravne Tunnels
description: Underground tunnel labyrinth located near the Bosnian Pyramids.
fun_fact: Visitors claim the air in the tunnels has healing properties due to high ions.

name: Old Town Počitelj
description: An open-air museum and historic village within a walled fortress.
fun_fact: Home to the longest-operating art colony in Southeast Europe.

name: Tito's Bunker
description: A massive top-secret underground atomic shelter built for the Yugoslav elite.
fun_fact: It was one of the most expensive structures built in the former Yugoslavia.

name: Umoljani Village
description: Ancient mountain village famous for the legend of the 'Cold Snake'.
fun_fact: Features unique tombstones and a mosque with a wooden minaret.

name: Bijambare Caves
description: A protected landscape with five caves and beautiful pine forests.
fun_fact: The 'Middle Cave' is famous for its acoustics and is called the Music Hall.

name: Bobovac Fortress
description: The seat of the Bosnian kings and the site of the royal burial chapel.
fun_fact: It was the last place where the Bosnian royal crown was kept.

name: Art Gallery of BiH
description: The oldest and most important art institution in the country, featuring over 6,000 works of art.
fun_fact: The gallery was founded just after WWII to preserve the Bosnian artistic heritage.

name: Museum of Sarajevo 1878–1918
description: A museum located at the corner where the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand took place.
fun_fact: The museum building was originally a shop before becoming one of the most famous street corners in history.

name: Musić-Begovina
description: A residential complex that is a masterpiece of 19th-century Mediterranean-Ottoman architecture.
fun_fact: The complex includes a private garden and a distinct layout designed for summer cooling.

name: Maculje Stećci Necropolis
description: A high-altitude necropolis featuring unique 'apple-shaped' tombstones.
fun_fact: It is situated at 1,200 meters above sea level, offering views of the Central Bosnian mountains.

name: Fortress of Soko Grad
description: The ruins of a medieval fortress that served as a strategic watchpoint in North Bosnia.
fun_fact: The fortress was built on a steep limestone ridge that made it nearly impregnable.

name: Ljubuški Fortress (Herceg Stjepan)
description: A medieval fortress built on the Butorovica hill, later expanded by the Ottomans.
fun_fact: It is the only fortress in the coastal hinterland that was never fully conquered by the Venetians.

name: St. Mary’s Church & St. Luke’s Tower
description: The coronation site of the last Bosnian king, later converted into a mosque and then ruined.
fun_fact: St. Luke’s Tower is the only preserved medieval belfry in the mainland Balkans.

name: Church of the Holy Virgin
description: Home to the 'Čajniče Krasnica', the only miracle-working icon of the Virgin Mary in BiH.
fun_fact: The icon is believed by locals to have been painted by the Apostle Luke.

name: Old Bridge in Mostar (Museum)
description: A museum located inside the Tara and Halebija towers of the Stari Most bridge.
fun_fact: The museum includes an underground section where you can see the original 16th-century foundations.

name: Necropolis Mramorje in Musići
description: A medieval cemetery with 43 tombstones, including rare gable-shaped stećci.
fun_fact: The site is surrounded by dense coniferous forests, typical of the Olovo region.

name: Fortress of Glamoč
description: A hilltop fortress featuring a unique circular 'Tabija' tower from the Ottoman period.
fun_fact: The fortress was a vital link in the 'Kliški Sandžak' defense line against the Venetians.

name: Husein-Kapetan Gradaščević Mosque
description: A large mosque built by the 'Dragon of Bosnia' near his family castle.
fun_fact: The mosque's minaret is 40 meters high, making it a landmark of the Posavina region.

name: Olympic Museum
description: A museum dedicated to the 14th Winter Olympic Games held in Sarajevo in 1984.
fun_fact: The museum is housed in the Mandić villa, which was the first building destroyed during the 1992 siege.

name: Tvrđava Soko (Šipovo)
description: The remains of a medieval fortress located above the canyon of the river Sokočnica.
fun_fact: The fortress is mentioned in historical documents as early as 1363.

name: Brusa Bezistan
description: A 16th-century covered market built by Rustem-pasha, now housing part of the Sarajevo Museum.
fun_fact: The building features six large and two small domes, a classic example of Ottoman trade architecture.

name: Franciscan Monastery Kraljeva Sutjeska
description: A spiritual and cultural center for centuries, holding the archives of the Bosnian state.
fun_fact: It houses the oldest painting in Bosnia, 'The Adoration of the Magi' from the 15th century.

name: Hadži-Beg Fortress (Hutovo)
description: The only fortress in the Neum hinterland, once ruled by the eccentric Hadži-Beg.
fun_fact: Hadži-Beg was known for his semi-independent rule and his frequent conflicts with the Vizier of Travnik.

name: Mehmed-Beg Kapetanović Tower
description: A 19th-century residential tower built for the local captain and nobleman.
fun_fact: The tower is a rare surviving example of a fortified residential 'kula' in the Herzegovina region.

name: Stećci Necropolis Kalufi
description: The largest necropolis of stećci in Bosnia and Herzegovina, with 452 tombstones.
fun_fact: Despite its size, this necropolis is rarely visited due to its remote mountain location.

name: Fortress of Prozor
description: The ruins of a medieval fortress that guarded the passage between Central Bosnia and Herzegovina.
fun_fact: It was a strategic stronghold for the Kotromanić royal dynasty.

name: Gazi Husrev-beg Library
description: One of the oldest libraries in Europe, housing over 10,000 Islamic manuscripts.
fun_fact: The library's collection was saved during the 1990s war by people hiding books in private homes.

name: Museum of the Second Session of AVNOJ
description: The museum dedicated to the 1943 meeting where the federal state of Yugoslavia was designed.
fun_fact: The museum preserves the original chairs and tables used by the delegates during the 1943 meeting.

name: Tvrđava Novi Grad
description: A 19th-century fortress on the banks of the Una and Sana rivers.
fun_fact: The fortress marks the historic border point between the Ottoman and Austro-Hungarian empires.

name: Franciscan Monastery Plehan
description: A modern monastery built on the ruins of one destroyed in 1992, featuring contemporary art.
fun_fact: The monastery is known as the 'Religious Art Center' due to its vast collection of modern sculptures.

name: Stara Čaršija u Gradačcu
description: The old commercial heart of Gradačac, centered around the Captain’s castle.
fun_fact: The area still maintains the traditional 'čardak' style houses typical of northern Bosnia.

name: Roman Mosaic at Skelani
description: Extensive remains of Roman floor mosaics from a 4th-century administrative center.
fun_fact: The mosaics were discovered relatively recently (2008) and are some of the best-preserved in the region.

name: Fortress of Orašac
description: A small but strategically vital Ottoman-era fortress overlooking the Una river.
fun_fact: The fortress was part of the westernmost defensive ring of the Ottoman Empire.

name: Svrzo's House Annex
description: A separate wing of the famous Svrzo's house that served as the business quarters.
fun_fact: It demonstrates how 18th-century Bosnian merchants separated their family life from their commercial deals.

name: Kuršumlija Madrasa
description: A 16th-century high school for Islamic studies, known for its lead-covered domes.
fun_fact: The name 'Kuršumlija' comes from the Turkish word for lead (kurşun), which covers the roof.

name: Old Town of Visoko (Čajangrad)
description: The ruins of a medieval fortress that guarded the central Bosnian trade routes.
fun_fact: It was one of the many fortifications that formed the defense system for the royal court in Moštre.

name: Bridge on the Žepa River
description: An Ottoman stone bridge, famously described in a short story by Ivo Andrić.
fun_fact: The bridge was relocated in 1966 due to the construction of a hydroelectric power plant on the Drina.

name: Fortress of Krupa na Uni
description: A fortress situated on a small island in the Una river, integrated into the town.
fun_fact: The fortress walls are so close to the water that they appear to rise directly out of the Una river.

name: Sarajevo Clock Tower (Sahat-kula)
description: The only public clock in the world that keeps lunar time (a la turca).
fun_fact: The clock is set to strike 12:00 exactly at sunset to mark the time for evening prayers.

name: Vareš Old Church of St. Michael
description: The oldest Catholic church in Bosnia that was never converted or destroyed throughout Ottoman rule.
fun_fact: The church is built of stone and wood and looks more like a traditional house to avoid attracting attention.

name: Stećci Necropolis Grebnice
description: A necropolis located on a ridge with tombstones featuring unique cross and shield reliefs.
fun_fact: It is part of the high-concentration area of stećci around Stolac, a hotspot for medieval archeology.

name: Fortress of Livno (Bistrica)
description: A fortification complex above the source of the river Bistrica, known as 'Vejs Kula'.
fun_fact: The fortress once housed a massive grain storage to feed the border garrisons.

name: Museum of the Franciscan Monastery Gorica
description: A museum housing an ethnological collection and works by the painter Gabriel Jurkić.
fun_fact: It contains one of the best-preserved collections of traditional folk costumes from western Bosnia.

name: Old Mosque in Pliva
description: A rare wooden mosque built in a style unique to the forest regions of Bosnia.
fun_fact: The mosque's minaret is made entirely of wood, using no metal nails in its original construction.

name: Fortress of Gradina (Cazin)
description: A medieval fortress that was once the seat of the Bishops of Knin.
fun_fact: The fortress was a key northern defense point before the Ottoman conquest of Bihać.

name: Museum of the Battle for the Wounded
description: A museum dedicated to the Battle of the Neretva, featuring a collapsed bridge in the river.
fun_fact: The collapsed bridge in the river was actually blown up twice—once during the war and once for a 1969 film.

name: Gornji Grad Fortress
description: A medieval fortress guarding the Spreča valley, later expanded by the Ottomans.
fun_fact: The fortress offers a view of the entire industrial basin of northern Bosnia.

name: Gradina in Gornji Pale
description: The remains of a medieval fortified residence of the Pavlović noble family.
fun_fact: It was one of the key defensive points protecting the road to the royal city of Bobovac.

name: Monastery of St. Nicholas
description: A 14th-century Serbian Orthodox monastery known for its unique fresco paintings.
fun_fact: The monastery was a major center for copying manuscripts during the Ottoman period.

name: Old Mosque in Šerići
description: A rare example of a wooden mosque with a porch and a wooden minaret, preserved in its original form.
fun_fact: It is one of the few wooden mosques in the Tuzla region that survived the wars of the 20th century.

name: Fortress of Teočak
description: A medieval fortress famous for its 'Old Town' and the mosque of Fethija built within its walls.
fun_fact: The fortress was the seat of the Hungarian puppet-king of Bosnia, Nikola Iločki.

name: St. Anne's Church
description: A historic monastery church located in the picturesque valley of the Gomionica river.
fun_fact: Petar Kočić, a famous Bosnian writer, spent part of his childhood in this monastery.

name: Roman Military Camp Castrum
description: Archeological remains of a Roman military camp that later became the foundation for Doboj fortress.
fun_fact: It served as a major logistics hub for Roman troops moving toward the Danube.

name: Old Town of Ključ
description: The fortress where the last Bosnian king, Stjepan Tomašević, was captured by the Ottomans.
fun_fact: The capture of this fortress in 1463 marked the official fall of the Bosnian Kingdom.

name: Bijela Mosque in Brčko
description: A beautiful 19th-century mosque located in the center of Brčko, featuring distinct white walls.
fun_fact: It is the oldest mosque in the city and a symbol of the multicultural spirit of Brčko.

name: Mijat’s Cave (Mijatova pećina)
description: A high-altitude cave on Mt. Vran where the legendary hajduk Mijat Tomić gathered his band.
fun_fact: Mijat Tomić is a legendary figure in folk songs, celebrated as a protector of the poor against Ottoman rule.

name: Old Town of Kozarac
description: A renovated Ottoman-era fortress at the foot of the Kozara Mountain.
fun_fact: The town was once a significant administrative center of the Turkish captaincy.

name: Church of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary
description: A historic Catholic church that stands as a landmark of the city’s skyline.
fun_fact: The church features beautiful architectural details and is a key symbol of the city's multicultural heritage.

name: Church of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary
description: A historic Catholic church that stands as a landmark of the city’s skyline.
fun_fact: The church features beautiful stained glass windows imported from Austria in the early 1900s.

name: Fortress of Vrnograč
description: A small, strategic medieval fort located on the border between Bosnia and Croatia.
fun_fact: It was part of the 'Captaincy of the Una' defensive line against the Habsburg Empire.

name: Kuvet-ul-Islam Mosque
description: A central mosque in Zvornik, rebuilt after the war, representing the resilience of the local community.
fun_fact: The mosque is situated right on the bank of the Drina river, overlooking the border with Serbia.

name: Stari Grad Visoki
description: The ruins of the medieval royal city of Visoki, located on top of the Visočica hill.
fun_fact: The charter of the Bosnian State was signed here by King Tvrtko I in 1355.

name: Monastery of Tavna
description: A 14th-century monastery located at the confluence of the rivers Tavna and Drina.
fun_fact: The monastery is famous for its architecture, which resembles the style of the famous Studenica monastery in Serbia.

name: Old Bridge in Klepci
description: The oldest Ottoman bridge in Herzegovina, predating the Stari Most in Mostar.
fun_fact: It was built in 1517 by Mustafa-bey and served as the main crossing for caravans toward the coast.

name: Fortress of Klobuk
description: A remote fortress located on a cliff, one of the last strongholds of the Bosnian state.
fun_fact: Klobuk was notoriously difficult to conquer due to its position on a 200m vertical drop.

name: St. George’s Church in Sopotnica
description: The site of the first printing house in Bosnia and Herzegovina, founded in 1519.
fun_fact: The Goražde printing house produced liturgical books that are now kept in museums across the world.

name: Fortress of Sokol u Usori
description: A medieval fortress that once belonged to the local ban and noble families.
fun_fact: It was part of the 'Lower Lands' (Donji Kraji) defense system in medieval Bosnia.

name: Old Tower in Cazin
description: A preserved Ottoman watchtower that served as a communication point between border forts.
fun_fact: The tower was used to light signal fires to warn of approaching enemy armies.

name: Necropolis of Stećci in Bečani
description: A UNESCO-listed necropolis featuring uniquely tall and decorated medieval tombstones.
fun_fact: The site is surrounded by pristine nature in the mountainous region of Eastern Bosnia.

name: Fortress of Novi Grad (Derventa)
description: The ruins of a late medieval and Ottoman fortress on the Ukrina river.
fun_fact: The fortress controlled the river trade routes between the Sava river and the Bosnian interior.

name: Spomenik Krila Slobode (Žuč)
description: A massive memorial monument on Žuč hill dedicated to the defenders of Sarajevo during the 1990s siege.
keywords: war, defense, wings, Žuč, Sarajevo, viewpoint
fun_fact: The monument symbolizes the breakthrough and freedom of the city, offering a 360-degree view of Sarajevo.

name: Mount Žuč
description: A strategic hill and a site of key battles during the Siege of Sarajevo, now a memorial park.
fun_fact: The area is being transformed into a large memorial and recreational park with museums and trenches.

name: Sarajevo Cable Car (Žičara)
description: A modern cable car connecting the old town (Bistrik) with the Trebević mountain.
keywords: viewpoint, cable car, Trebević, Sarajevo, panoramic
fun_fact: The original cable car was built in 1959, destroyed during the war, and reopened as a brand new system in 2018.

name: Trebević Bobsleigh Track
description: The remains of the bobsleigh and luge track built for the 1984 Winter Olympics.
fun_fact: The track is now a world-famous spot for graffiti artists and extreme sports like downhill mountain biking.

name: Mount Trebević
description: A mountain overlooking Sarajevo, known as the 'lungs of the city,' offering hiking trails and viewpoints.
fun_fact: During the 1984 Olympics, it hosted several alpine and sliding competitions.

name: Mila Necropolis
description: The coronation and burial site of Bosnian kings and the location of the first Bosnian Parliament.
fun_fact: This is where King Tvrtko I was crowned in 1377 and where the Charter of King Stephen Ostoja was signed in 1404.

name: Lukin Mlin (Luke's Mill)
description: A rare preserved watermill on the Bosna river that has been operational for over a century.
fun_fact: The mill still uses traditional stone grinding methods to produce organic flour, maintaining a 100-year-old family tradition.

name: Ostrovica Castle
description: A massive medieval fortress overlooking the Una river, once a key defensive point of the kingdom.
fun_fact: The fortress was built on a steep hill that provided a 360-degree view, making it one of the most impregnable in the region.

name: Tvrđava Srebrenik
description: The best-preserved medieval castle in Bosnia, perched on a 450m high rock.
fun_fact: The only way to enter the fortress is via a narrow wooden bridge over a deep dry moat.

name: Atik Mosque
description: The oldest mosque in Bijeljina, featuring rare architectural elements from the 16th century.
fun_fact: The mosque was built by Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent and is a national monument of BiH.

name: Gradina Fortress
description: The ruins of a medieval fortress that served as the residence of the noble Pavlović family.
fun_fact: The fortress controlled the 'Carski put' (Imperial Road) that connected Sarajevo with Constantinople during the Ottoman era.

name: Franciscan Monastery of St. Catherine
description: A 14th-century monastery famous for its museum and the tradition of horseshoeing eggs.
fun_fact: The museum holds a unique collection of minerals and the famous 'horseshoed egg' - a symbol of blacksmith skill.

name: Old Stone Bridge
description: An elegant 16th-century bridge crossing the Žepa river, a masterpiece of Ottoman engineering.
fun_fact: The bridge was famously immortalized in the prose of Nobel laureate Ivo Andrić and was moved stone-by-stone in 1966.

name: Pavlović Castle (Borač)
description: The remains of one of the largest medieval fortified cities in Bosnia, the seat of the Pavlović family.
fun_fact: The fortress had 11 towers and was one of the most important administrative centers of medieval Bosnia.

name: Savić House
description: The oldest preserved urban house in Banja Luka, representing 19th-century architecture.
fun_fact: The house is a rare example of how the wealthy merchant families of Banja Luka lived 150 years ago.

name: Olovo City Museum
description: A local museum showcasing the rich mining history and medieval heritage of the Olovo region.
fun_fact: Olovo was one of the most important lead mining centers in the medieval Balkans, giving the town its name.

name: Fortica Mostar
description: A skywalk and adventure park on a hill above Mostar, featuring a giant national flag.
fun_fact: The 35-meter long glass skywalk offers a terrifyingly beautiful view of the city and the Old Bridge.

name: Makljen Spite Monument (The Fist)
description: The remains of a massive monument 'Poet of the Revolution' on the Makljen pass.
fun_fact: Although blown up in 2000, its skeletal concrete frame remains a hauntingly striking landmark.

name: Smrike Necropolis
description: A unique memorial complex dedicated to WWII victims, designed by Bogdan Bogdanović.
fun_fact: The site features 12 stone 'guardians' with bird-like eyes, typical of Bogdanović's surrealist style.

name: Garavice Memorial Park
description: A sprawling memorial site on a hill dedicated to the victims of fascist terror in WWII.
fun_fact: The park consists of 15 massive stone pillars designed by Bogdan Bogdanović in a mystical, organic style.

name: Partisan Memorial Cemetery
description: A monumental cemetery built to honor the fallen partisans, resembling an abstract stone city.
fun_fact: It is one of the most complex and beautiful examples of necropolis architecture in the world.

name: Vraca Memorial Park
description: A site of execution during WWII turned into a memorial park on the slopes of Trebević.
fun_fact: The park is built around an old Austro-Hungarian fortress and contains the names of 11,000 victims.

name: Ravna Planina Resort
description: A modern four-season mountain resort with a ski slope, a gondola lift, and an artificial lake for recreational activities.
keywords: ski, gondola, Pale, nature, lake, viewpoint
fun_fact: The newly built gondola provides a seamless panoramic connection between the base of the mountain and the top station's lake area.

name: Prokoško Lake
description: A glacial lake surrounded by traditional wooden shepherd huts on Vranica mountain.
fun_fact: Home to the endemic Triton (Triturus alpestris reiseri) salamander and a unique ethno-village experience.

name: Svetište Gospe Olovske
description: The oldest Marian shrine in the Balkans, a place of pilgrimage for over seven centuries.
fun_fact: It is mentioned in Dubrovnik records as early as 1375 and is visited by people of all faiths.

name: Banja Aquaterm
description: A modern medical spa center using healing thermo-mineral waters for rehabilitation.
fun_fact: The thermal water springs at a constant 34°C and is unique for its chemical composition in the region.

name: Obelisk u Bakićima
description: A mysterious 4-meter stone monolith decorated with medieval symbols of a boar and a snake.
fun_fact: Local legends associate the obelisk with the wedding of a giant or the tomb of a high-ranking noble.

name: Muška Voda (Konjuh)
description: A famous natural spring on Mount Konjuh, legendary for its medicinal and aphrodisiac properties.
fun_fact: Legend says the Ottoman elite used this water for longevity and vitality, earning it the name 'Male Water'.

name: Kiseljak Town Center
description: A small town known throughout Bosnia for its famous mineral water and specific flatbread with kajmak.
keywords: mineral water, kiseljak, pogacica, kajmak, tradition, lepina, food
fun_fact: The name 'Kiseljak' literally means 'sour water', referring to its natural carbonated mineral springs (kiselica).
